bestBHT.bht: As they climbed the mountain during the night, the disciples were overcome with drowsiness due to their simple habits, the late hour, and the physical exertion. However, it is important to note that they did not fall asleep, but rather kept awake through the whole experience. This was not a half-awake vision, but a real and tangible encounter. When they were fully alert, they witnessed the glory of Jesus, radiating an incredible splendor that awed them out of their sleep. This encounter would qualify them to become firsthand witnesses of His majesty, just as Jesus had intended.

Henry Alford: Not 'when they were awake,' as A.V., which is not the sense of the word,—but having kept awake through the whole.
The word seems to be expressly used here to shew that it was not merely a vision, seen in sleep.
Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: Perhaps 'having roused themselves up' may come near enough to the literal sense
qualifying them to become 'eye-witnesses of His majesty'
Marvin Vincent: It was but natural for these men of simple habits, at night, and after the long ascent, and in the strong mountain air, to be heavy with sleep."
In quick reaction, after the overpowering influence of the strongest emotions, drowsiness would creep over their limbs and senses.
Drowsiness would creep over their limbs and senses.
Philip Schaff: It was probably at night, and their drowsiness was natural: but they did not go to sleep, for the next phrase means, yet having remained awake."
It was not a vision of half sleeping men.
Archibald T. Robertson: They had apparently climbed the mountain in the early part of the night and were now overcome with sleep as Jesus prolonged his prayer."

But when they were fully awake (διαγρηγορησαντες δε)... to become thoroughly awake (ingressive aorist tense also) as Revised Version has it. This is most likely correct. The Syriac Sinaitic has it 'When they awoke.' Certainly they had been through a strain.
His glory (την δοξαν αυτου). See also verse Luke 9:26 in the words of Jesus.
John Gill: Being weary with the labours of the day past, and it being now night, as is very probable, since that was an usual time Christ spent in prayer.
They were so heavy with sleep, that it was with difficulty they were awaked out of it, even by the rays of light and glory that were about them.
Such a lustre darted from these glorious forms, especially from the body of Christ, as at once surprised them out of their sleep.
John Wesley: They saw his glory — The very same expression in which it is described by St. John, John 1:14; and by St. Peter, 2 Peter 1:16.

bhtAttempts.bht: As they climbed the mountain during the night, the disciples were overcome with drowsiness due to their simple habits, the late hour, and the physical exertion. However, it is important to note that they did not fall asleep, but rather kept awake through the whole experience. This was not a half-awake vision, but a real and tangible encounter. When they were fully alert, they witnessed the glory of Jesus, radiating an incredible splendor that awed them out of their sleep. This encounter would qualify them to become firsthand witnesses of His majesty, just as Jesus had intended.

As they climbed the mountain, the disciples, being men of simple habits, grew heavy with sleep due to the late hour, their physical exertion, and the strong mountain air. However, they did not fall asleep but managed to keep awake throughout the entire experience. After they were fully alert and roused up, they were able to witness the glory of Jesus, which shone forth with a luminosity that startled them out of their drowsiness. This remarkable encounter would equip them to become firsthand eyewitnesses of His majesty.

As they made their way up the mountain, the disciples, fatigued from the day's labors and the late hour, succumbed to drowsiness in the strong mountain air. However, it is important to note that they managed to keep awake throughout the entire experience. Once fully alert and awakened, they were able to behold the remarkable glory emanating from Jesus. The brilliance of His presence astounded them, rousing them from their sleepy state. This encounter prepared them to witness and testify to His majestic power.

As the disciples ascended the mountain, the late hour and their simple habits caused them to grow heavy with sleep. However, it is important to note that they managed to keep awake and remain alert throughout the entire experience. When they were fully awakened, they were able to witness the glory of Jesus, whose radiance surpassed anything they had ever seen before. This encounter served as a transformative moment, equipping them to become firsthand eyewitnesses of His divine majesty.

As the disciples climbed the mountain, the long ascent coupled with the night setting and the strong mountain air caused them to grow heavy with sleep. Yet, they did not fall asleep. After fully awakening and rousing themselves up, they were able to witness the magnificent glory emanating from Jesus. His astonishing radiance astounded them, rousing them from their sleepy state. This encounter qualified them to become eye-witnesses of His divine majesty, marking a significant moment in their journey with Him.
